title: 111_hr4130
content: The "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" establishes a temporary Afghanistan war surtax under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This surtax applies to taxable years beginning after 2010 and increases the tax imposed on joint returns with net income tax liability. The surtax under the "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" is based on net income tax liability, with varying percentages and amounts based on income levels. The "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" imposes a surtax on individuals, trusts, and estates with net income tax liability, increasing the tax amount based on a specific table. The "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" imposes a surtax on individuals, trusts, and estates based on a specific table. For net income tax liability not over $11,300, the surtax is 1% of the liability. For income tax liability over $11,300 but not over $18,200, the surtax is $113 plus a percentage of the excess over $11,300. For income tax liability over $18,200, the surtax is $113 plus a percentage of $6,900, plus twice the percentage of the excess over $18,200. The "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" imposes a surtax on corporations with net income tax liability, increasing the tax by twice the applicable percentage determined by the President for each calendar year. The "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" imposes a surtax on corporations with net income tax liability, increasing the tax by twice the applicable percentage determined by the President for each calendar year. Certain exceptions related to military service apply, excluding members of the Armed Forces who received excludible compensation under section 112 during the taxable year or any year after September 11, 2001. The "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" imposes a surtax on corporations with net income tax liability, increasing the tax by twice the applicable percentage determined by the President for each calendar year. Exceptions related to military service apply, excluding members of the Armed Forces who received excludible compensation under section 112 during the taxable year or any year after September 11, 2001. Additionally, individuals who received a death gratuity under chapter 75 of title 10, United States Code, for a decedent who died on or after September 11, 2001, are also exempt from the surtax. The "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" imposes a surtax on individuals with adjusted gross income not exceeding $30,000. The net income tax liability is defined as the excess of regular tax liability and tax imposed by section 55, minus credits allowed under part IV. The President can delay the tax implementation for up to 1 year if the economy is deemed too weak. This tax is not considered as tax imposed by this chapter for certain purposes. The tax imposed under the "Share the Sacrifice Act of 2010" is not considered as tax imposed by this chapter for certain purposes. The tax does not apply if the applicable percentage is zero for a calendar year. Part VIII. Temporary Afghanistan War Surtax effective for taxable years after December 31, 2010. Amendment not considered a change in tax rate for section 15 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
